RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the occupants of the truck: Maria De Jesus Garcia, Lourdes Rangel-Campos, and others

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia: Defendant stopped by border patrol agents on an interstate highway in Texas, owner of the truck, appellant in the current case, with a vehicle that had an apparent heavy load, occupants exhibited suspicious behavior when approached, vehicle was traveling at forty to forty-five miles per hour, contesting the district court's refusal to allow post-verdict discovery through juror depositions, driver of the stopped vehicle, appellant arguing against the use of the Allen charge, seeking post-verdict discovery through juror depositions, defendant in a case where the trial judge denied a motion to interview jurors, stopped on an interstate highway in Texas 115 miles north of the Mexico/United States border, driver of a truck
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron: Agents who conducted the stop of Garcia's truck, applied the multi-factorial test to determine reasonable suspicion, observed suspicious behavior from occupants, used flashlight to observe vehicle occupants at night, testified about occupants' attempts to hide from the flashlight, had specialized training as border patrol agents, stopped the vehicle more than 100 miles from the United States-Mexican border, knew of recent smuggling activities in the area, claimed expertise to distinguish between characteristics of travelers who are illegal aliens and those lawfully present
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia, Lourdes Rangel-Ca: Individuals present in the vehicle stopped by agents Pruszenski and Baron, exhibited suspicious behavior when approached by border patrol agents, appeared unwashed and unkempt, tried to hide from agent's flashlight, reacted to a bright light at night, were in a vehicle with a heavily loaded camper shell
